reviewText: This re-remake of 'The Producers' has oceans of great stuff in it - catchy and well-staged tunes, great performances, excellent direction, plenty of laughs, and an all-round sense of fun that I haven't seen in a movie musical for aaaaages.Unfortunately, it's also too damn long. What works onstage doesn't necessarily work on  screen, and sadly, 'The Producers' is one or two numbers too long for its own good.Still, for the most part, it's an extremely enjoyable and worthwhile movie.Bookish, nervy accountant Leo Bloom (Matthew Broderick), while going over the books of failure-prone Broadway producer Max Bialystock (Nathan Lane), realises that with a little dishonesty and a lot of capital, they could make more money from a flop than a hit. Finding the best script for the job - 'Springtime for Hitler' by neo-Nazi Franz Liebkind (Will Ferrell) - and hiring all manner of talentless Broadway hangers-on, including Swedish bombshell Ulla (Uma Thurman), they set about making the worst show in the history of entertainment, to make the most money possible.Performances are manic, energetic and hilarious - particularly Nathan Lane's turn as Max, and Desperate Housewives' Roger Bart as Carmen - and the script is lively and funny. I'm very pleased that the production company decided to keep a decidedly 'theatrical' feel about the whole film - movements are stage-big, numbers are simple and elegant, and the whole look and feel of 'The Producers' hearkens very much back to a Hollywood of the 1940s and 1950s - big numbers, big voices and big visuals.The actual 'Springtime For Hitler' sequence is similarly hilarious, and similarly simplistic - but all the more rewarding for it. This is how all Broadway-to-Hollywood adaptations should be handled: forget the sex appeal, forget the movie polish, forget the dumbing-down - 'The Producers' gets it right.Sadly, 'The Producers' also suffers from the one big problem that almost all stage-to-screen adaptations suffer from - it's just too long. In a theatre, we rely on character interaction and dialogue or songs to keep our interest, but in a motion picture, with its more generous scope for visual creativity, we don't need the same level of content, and, as with 'Rent' and 'Chicago' before it, 'The Producers' doesn't quite manage to retain our attention or its own momentum to the end of the movie.But still, it's great fun, and well worth owning - but only if this sort of thing is your cup of tea. 'The Producers' is very good - but won't win any new fans to the genre.

reviewText: **1/2Few films have made as complete a round trip through the entertainment world as Mel Brooks' "The Producers," which started life as a movie in 1968, became a smash Tony Award winning Broadway musical in 2001, and now returns to the silver screen, all spruced up but with much of its heart taken out.Virtually everyone is familiar with the story of Max Bialystock, a down-on-his-luck Broadway producer who discovers that, through some loopholes in the tax laws, one can actually make more money from a show that flops than one that succeeds.  Thus, he and his milquetoast accountant, Leo Bloom, set about putting on the worst Broadway show of all time, a musical entitled "Springtime for Hitler," that is guaranteed to bomb at the box office, making the two producers instant millionaires.  What Max fails to take into account is the old show biz adage that "no one ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public," and, thus, much to his dismay, he soon finds himself with a certified hit on his hands.One of the problems "The Producers" faces right off the bat is the memories the audience brings with them of the original movie.  Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, good as they are in the lead roles (and they are VERY good), still cannot rise to the level of the great Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder who came before them.  One need only compare the two movies side by side and scene by scene to see that Mostel and Wilder literally own these roles.  That doesn't mean that one can't enjoy Lane's and Broderick's on-screen antics here - just that it helps if one doesn't come to the movie already prejudiced by over-familiarity with the source.Brooks himself has penned the musical score which features clever lyrics and jaunty, if not exactly memorable, tunes.  The song-and-dance numbers are reasonably well mounted, although Susan Stroman's direction leans, for the most part, towards the boxy and the stagy.When "The Producers" was first released in 1968, it seemed wildly iconoclastic, daring and cutting edge, a perfect reflection of the no-holds-barred, everything-goes decade that spawned it.  Now, coming back to us in the form of a high-priced, award-laden musical, set inexplicably in the 1950's, it feels strangely like a relic - old-fashioned, claustrophobic, stuffy and embalmed.  Gone is the freshness and immediacy and glorious bad taste that came with the original.  It`s just not vital anymore.There are still sporadic moments of pleasure to be had with this "Producers."  But it's not in any way comparable to the real thing.

reviewText: Only Mel Brooks could make this completely unenlightened, politically incorrect, stereotype-ridden musical and make it genuinely hilarious.  A national treasure, Brooks takes both the musical and the movies to new comic depths with "The Producers," his film adaptation of his recent broadway smash, which was itself a stage adaptation of the 1968 movie, "The Producers."  (Brooks not only knows that you don't change horses in mid-stream, you don't abandon the horse after it's been made into dog food.)Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick reprise their stage roles and the roles made famous by Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder in the original film.  While it's safe to say that neither Lane nor Broderick can equal Mostel and Wilder in the clowning-around department, they both got game.  "The Producers" is funny in the classic sense - there is no post-modern attempt at irony here, just plain old clever wordplay and slapstick.  Uma Thurman and Will Ferrell round out the Big Hollywood Names in the case, and they generally hold their own as an oversexed Scandinavian actress and a Hitler-sympathizing writer, respectively.Like many Mel Brooks movies, "The Producers" can wear a bit thin at times.  While many comedies bog down because they only have about fifteen to twenty funny minutes stretched into a 90-minute movie, Brooks' films almost get tedious because the humor never freaking stops!  Brooks crams jokes into the margins of the movie once he's finished building the structure - look for Broadway show posters advertising "King Leer" and "The Breaking Wind," for example.  Or the "Heil Hitler" salute from the chorus line of pigeons.  Or, in the closing credits, Will Ferrell (in character, of course) plugging the paperback edition of "Mein Kampf."  Again, nobody but Brooks could pull this off.The only truly bothersome element of the movie for me was Broderick's over-the-top nebbishy voice . . . it was almost (almost!) as annoying as Ben Stiller's Derek Zoolander voice or even Adam Sandler's Billy Madison.  But others have found Broderick's voice hliarous . . . it just didn't click for me.  Broderick's overall performance and his singing was excellent, however.If you still need more encouraging to check out "The Producers," read any of the dozens of reviews that discuss its beyond-outlandish plot.  One of the best ideas for a screenplay in decades deserves to be remade by men and women of such comic talent as Brooks' ensemble.  Check it out.

reviewText: There is an obvious urge when reviewing this movie to compare it to the earlier version, but this is unfair. This movie is not a "remake" as such, but a different presentation of the basic story.  It needs to be reviewed on its own lack of merit.I simply cannot believe that this treatment was a hit on Broadway and received numerous awards, but people have told me that the theatre version was much better.Don't mistake though, this movie is awful, and for a multitude of reasons.  I watched it to the very end, mostly out of curiosity and hoping it would get better.  It never did.The acting is either over the top, or wooden.  Matthew Broderick is particularly bad, there's no life in his character- and Nathan Lane seems to be unable to make up his mind between taking the part of Max for his own or doing a lousy imitation of Zero Mostel.  Uma Thurman was a questionable choice for Ulla. Her accent is inconsistent, she towers over her co-stars- neither of which are tall men, and when you boil it down, she is somewhat gangley and strange looking.  Don't even get me started on how bad Will Ferrell is.  His take on Franz is pathetic.  He tries to give his character the wild-eyed fanaticism that it requires, but you get the overall impression that he's just camping it up and actually making fun of it.  He's no Kenneth Mars.  The sequence on the roof where Max and Leo have him sign the contract- one of the funniest parts of the original movie- is probably the worst part of this one.The supporting cast is lousy too. The character of "Carmen Ghia" comes to mind. Originally the effeminate partner of Roger Debris, he comes off as a drill sergeant in a lousy haircut and tight clothes.Even the jokes that were lifted from the original movie have been stepped on or rearranged to where they aren't funny. I think I may have laughed twice during the whole movie, and that was at the goofy show posters in Max's office.This movie is also a rather strange "musical." When I saw "Chicago" for the first time, I found myself humming the tunes.  I cannot recall one from this movie.I also have many problems with the needless revisions in the original plot.Everyone who watched the original movie knew that Max "went right" when he selected LSD as his Hitler.  His portrayal of Hitler was hilarious, and Franz Liebkind's reaction to it convinced the audience that the play was a comedy.  However, LSD is absent from this movie.  The Hitler part goes- eventually- to Debris!  There is nothing really funny about the Hitler portrayed by him, or his material.  Actually, it's somewhat boring.  How did people interpret this to be comedic?Having Leo married and off to Rio with Ulla did nothing either.  Apparently it was just another device to work more unmemorable music into the movie.Finally, there is the length of this thing- OVER TWO HOURS!  It's a marathon.  In the original movie they blew up the theatre.  They should have done it here too- and much sooner.However, I didn't hate the whole thing- the "pearl" girls were quite attractive.  I've watched their dance sequence several times- with the sound off.This movie was a box office flop, disappearing from theatres and going to DVD almost instantly.  I wonder how much money Mel Brooks managed to raise to produce it?

reviewText: First, "The Producers" was a comedy movie by Mel Brooks.  Then, "The Producers" was a Broadway musical.  Now, "The Producers" is a movie again, and this time it's a musical as well as proof that Mel Brook's ideas never cease to be funny.If you already know the concept of "The Producers", there's not much of a plot to spoil.  Down on his luck Broadway producer Max Bialystock (Nathan Lane) convinces his neurotic accountant (Matthew Broderick) to be his partner in crime.  Together, the duo concoct a scheme to defraud Bialystock's investors by intentionally producing a flop and then run off with millions.  Then there's a neo-Nazi playwright (Will Ferrell), a barely in the closet directorial team (Gary Beach and Roger Bart), the extremely sexy Uma Thurman, and several awkward moments involving little old ladies, leading up to the staging of "Springtime for Hitler."  But then the intended flop is misinterpreted as a biting satire and becomes a hit, leaving the two frantic producers thinking fast to avoid prison time.From beginning to end, "The Producers" is filled with sharp jokes, most of them beautifully politically incorrect, but none of them crude.  Of course, when has Mel Brooks, the genius behind "Spaceballs" ever not been funny?  Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, both of whom have already played their roles on Broadway, play their roles to perfection, wearing their characters as comfortably as their own skin.  Will Ferrell's also great in his role.  Like Mel Brooks, he's never been unfunny.  Most importantly, everyone in the cast seems to genuinely be enjoying themselves, playing their parts strictly for laughs and making the most extravagant dance steps look natural.The highlight of the film is the staging of "Springtime for Hitler", a hilariously offensive number with such lyrical gems as "We're marching to a faster pace, look out, here comes the master race" and "Don't be stupid, be a smarty, come and join the Nazi party."  The other songs are catchy, and most of them add to the comic genius of the film, but, as with all musicals, some of the song and dance numbers fall flat.  Also, the ending seems just a little contrived and tacked-on.  Still, "The Producers" is overall the funniest musical comedy since Joseph L. Mankiewitz's "Guys and Dolls."

reviewText: Max Bialystock's (Nathan Lane) latest Broadway flop, "Happy Guy", a musical based on "Hamlet", has just opened and closed on the same night. His accountant, Leo Bloom (Matthew Broderick) reviews the books and realizes Max raised $2,000 more than he spent on the show. Because the show flopped, this isn't a huge problem, leading Leo to surmise that a producer could make more from a flop than a hit. Max latches onto the idea and they partner to find a surefire stinker. Max and Leo stumble upon "Springtime for Hitler" by Franz Liebkind (Will Ferrell), the perfect candidate and then hire the worst director on Broadway, Roger De Bris (Gary Beach) and his "common law" assistant Carmen Ghia (Roger Bart). All the makings of a surefire flop. Right?Mel Brooks' "The Producers" returns to the big screen, via the Great White Way, in this musical version starring many of the same actors who appeared in the show on Broadway. This new version is fun, slightly different, more of a compliment, than a replacement, to the original starring Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder.Lane and Broderick are both very good. Lane bears a striking resemblance to Mostel and, initially, I found this to be distracting. Physically, he could almost be Mostel's doppelganger down to the greasy comb-over. But after a while, you just have to let it go. Yes, he looks and acts like the famous comedian, but Lane is a funny guy in his own right. And a pretty good singer. The combination of his manic energy and his ability to sing, make it easy to see why Lane is always such a hit on Broadway. Strangely, Lane had another huge hit on Broadway some years ago with a new production of "A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum" in which he took on the role originated by, you guessed it, Zero Mostel.And Lane, with his rich history on Broadway, is a great choice to reinterpret Bialystock. He doesn't reinterpret so much as he refocuses. Bialystock is a desperate man, mounting one flop after another, desperate for the next chance at a hit. Each of these flops takes more out of him that he cares to let on, or admit to. His investors, a group of female senior citizens, complete with blue hair and walkers, will give him their `checkie' only after a little `touch me- feel me'. Lane humorously conveys the desperation and resignation his character has come to realize. Much more attracted to his new secretary, Ulla (Uma Thurman), a Swedish bombshell, he realizes the geriatric set is his bread and butter and he has to keep them happy.Matthew Broderick is a big surprise. He hasn't been this funny, this uninhibited in a long time, since perhaps "Ferris Bueller's Day Off". As Leo Bloom, he only hints at Gene Wilder's performance, making the role his own. The moment when he freaks out and reveals his security blanket is a truly funny bit, immediately creating the character, neuroses and all.Perhaps the biggest surprise is that Uma Thurman can sing and dance, assuming someone isn't singing for her. As Ulla, she makes the dumb vixen believable. But in the performance, we get a sense that she isn't just dumb; there is maybe just a little bit more to her. Sure she's beautiful, she's dumb, but she also has dreams, wants to fall in love.Of course, the main difference between the two film versions, the main reason the film was remade, is the addition of music. Someone somewhere recognized that the material, about Broadway producers trying to mount a huge flop, was a natural to be a musical in its own right. The 1968 version only had a little music, during the actual stage production. This new version has music throughout, providing homage to the musicals of the 40s and 50s.I'm not sure why they made this decision, but "The Producers" is a very old-fashioned musical. It was the right decision and I even get the sense it was a calculated decision. Let's face it. The demographic that goes to see a Broadway musical isn't getting any younger. Rather than attempt to get this group to enjoy a more modern musical, they have catered to this demographic, turning back the clock and making "The Producers" homage to the great studio musicals. The calculation clearly paid off. The Broadway show earned one of the highest one day ticket sales ever recorded.The film retains many of these old-fashioned elements, leading us to expect Gene Kelly or Fred Astaire to appear at any moment. It may not be groundbreaking, but it works. In "I Wanna Be a Producer", Matthew Broderick escapes a mind-numbing job as an accountant and imagines dancing with an ever-increasing cast of dancing girls up, down, over and across steps reflecting his name in lights. Broderick and Lane share "We Can Do It", each singing different verses, until they are soon singing the same song. Lane and Thurman pay homage to Astaire and Rogers as they dance through Bialystock's newly painted white office, as tinges of blue glow through out. All of this works because it is done well and could've been lifted straight from a Gene Kelly film.It is refreshing to watch a "Mel Brooks' Film" again. Let's face it. "Blazing Saddles" would never be made today in a Hollywood filled with people afraid of what might offend someone. "Blazing Saddles" is a hilarious film, but many of the jokes are at the expense of particular types of people. The "outrageous" comedies we see today are all about Caucasians getting into "outrageous" situations. "The Producers" is a mild throwback to an era that would make a "Mel Brooks' Film", at least when they were funny. Brooks' funniest films are his most outrageous, filled with many un-PC jokes. "The Producers" is a milder, tamer, but still funny version of the old Mel Brooks we all loved. Roger De Bris (Gary Beach) and Carmen Ghia (Roger Bart) are the kind of characters only Mel Brooks would, could put in a film. By the time Brooks is done, we have a man dressing in a ball gown and wig, the Village People dancing down stairs and a gay swami all added to the mix. And it's funny.I'm not sure how the idea popped into Mel Brooks' head, but it was a good idea and now "The Producers" has come full circle.
summary: A Nice Compliment to the Original

reviewText: The answer is, not many places. The film of the musical of the original movie brings back a bunch of the stage's stars, notably Matthew Broderick and Nathan Lane, to try and recapture what brought Broadway ticket holders out in droves. However, this looks like the old fashioned musical-to-film style where the movie often looks like the stage play simply acted out for the cameras. Given that this ruse was pivotal tothe original Producers, it's virtually intact from the first. naturally, it's also the film's highlight.Even with that classic set piece, "The Producers" fails to catch fire. The bits are strung out and uneven, and never meet the heights of the original. Matthew Broderick in particular seems out of his league here, playing Leo as a wooden nebbish, while Nathan Lane channels Zero Mostel adequately. Even with all this going for it, "The Producers" can't seem to maintain the timing it needs to be a flat out success. reviewText: The remake of The Producers isn't quite the catastrophe it's been painted, though it's still a long way from a success. Some of its problems can be traced to the stage show - Mel Brooks' musical score is still thin despite much improved orchestration and, though toned down from his deeply irritating stage performance, Matthew Broderick misjudges things quite badly more often than not, while there's no excuse for flattening 'Springtime For Hitler' by padding it out to three times its length (indeed, this remake clocks in at three-quarters of an hour longer than the original). Some problems are unique to the film version: certainly if you're one of the many wondering why some people find Will Ferrell funny, you'll find no answer here in his terrible performance, while cutting the 'King of Broadway' number (to be found among the deleted scenes on the DVD) seems a misjudgement as it's one of the funnier and better staged numbers.Nathan Lane does well enough as Bialystock, although he's given a little too much rope to be at his best, Uma Thurman is better than expected and even Susan Strohman's direction isn't as bad as it's been made out, far more cinematic than her critics claim although it doesn't entirely escape the feeling that the only reason there isn't a fourth wall on screen is because there wasn't one in the theatre. Still, the 'I Want to Be a Producer' production number is an impressive throwback to some of the lesser MGM musicals, and the theatricality of 'That Face' works surprisingly well. It's certainly better than the screen versions of many Broadway musicals churned out in the 60s or 70s, but the tighter-paced and much better scripted original needn't worry about it stealing its thunder.Decent extras include 19 minutes of deleted scenes, a 15-minute blooper reel and short about the 'I Want to be a Producer' number, though Susan Strohman's commentary doesn't exactly command your attention.
summary: Not quite a Bialystock & Bloom production, but no triumph either

reviewText: From the very beginning, director Susan Stroman's intention is obvious. Stroman, who also directed the critically acclaimed Broadway original stage production of `The Producers,' must have thought it best to film the stage production as it is, instead of introducing any cinematic skills into it. True, she did add the glitter of the golden era of MGM musicals with superb production designs, but the entire feeling of watching this film is like seeing the well-choreographed singers and dancers through a video camera set in front of the Broadway stage.Having said that, thanks to the superb acting from the cast, I admit the film remains very entertaining. In spite of staleness seen in several parts of the film, at least it worked for me, and the pair of Matthew Broderick and Nathan Lane, who need to produce the worst stage ever to get rich quickly, is fun to see. I don't say they are better than the former pair of Gene Wilder and Zero Mostel in the original film, and some part of their performances look as if repeating the turns of Wilder/Mostel (Broderick's nervous accountant looks like a copy of funnier and more sentimental Wilder's), but they are truly in character, which explains their huge success on stage, and yes, I know it is unfair to make comparison here with the older film made 38 years ago.But when the capable supporting actors appear on the screen after the earlier chapters, the newer version gets better. Actually, the more supports it shows, the better it gets. See the hilarious pigeon-keeping writer Will Ferrell and sexy Swedish girl Uma Thurman, and you know what I mean. Gary Beach and Roger Bart are real hoot, stealing every scene from the leads with excellent performances. And of course the most `terrible' musical you've ever seen `Springtime for Hitler.' It was a real showstopper in the original Mel Brookes film, and it still is now with more ridiculous costumes and the deliciously silly dancing of Storm Troopers. And again with Gary Beach and his brief but fantastic turn as Fuhrer.If you insist that this should be a cinema, not a filmed record of the stage, then you will dislike `The Producers' for the lack of any cinematic style to re-conceptualize the material. I don't know why Mel Brooks (who briefly appears at the VERY end of the film) handed the job of direction to Susan Stroman, which is obviously a mistake as film director if not a choreographer. I enjoyed the film for what it is, but I don't know that you would feel the same way after seeing this.
summary: (3.5 STARS) Very Entertaining Musical But You May Not Like the Film's Stagy Approach

reviewText: Personally, I don't think The Producers is a spectacular musical. The story is witty and clever, but after the Springtime for Hitler scene, it falls flat. The songs are very forgettable. Majority of the songs are either too silly, mediocre, or just plain not good, some which seem to come off as fillers. Kind of a shame, since songs in musicals are the highlight of the show! Also, even though Nathan Lane and Matthew Brodwick make a great team, i just don't think Matthew is a great actor. He has no personality or character whatswhoever, just plain bland. Nathan Lane steals the show! Despite that, there were a few laugh out loud scenes that i really enjoyed (such as the scenes with Will Farrel as Franz Liebkind, and Gary Beach with his gay musical number). And despite the subject matter of the awkward play within a play, "Springtime for Hitler," it was the most hilarious scene of the movie. After that, the rest of the play feels extremely rushed, if not boring and too predictable. Not something worth buying, but still a nice rental for a Saturday night.

reviewText: I have always listed the 1968 "Producers" as the all-time funniest movie ever (followed very closely by Mel Brooks' equally side-splitting "Young Frankenstein." I very much wanted to see the play, but it didn't happen for me.So when the movie-oh horrors, the REMAKE--came out, I had mixed feelings, only I knew it wasn't really a remake but it was the play taken from the 1968 version made into a movie! (Whew)Anyway, I began to watch, and my very first thought was a snide: "Matthew Broderick is no Gene Wilder." Until the blue blanket scene. And by the time hysterical Broderick is on the floor in terror, squealing "You're going to JUMP on me! Please don't JUMP on me!" I was finished. I laughed as long and hard during this movie as the last one, but they really cannot be compared. The first was a classic; this is a hilariously funny musical with the best parts of the first movie pretty much left intact.Where do I start with the acting? Nathan Lane was/is a magnificent Max Bialystock, as good as or even better than Zero Mostel. Broderick does not play Bloom the way Wilder did, and good for him. He made the role completely his own. I thought Uma Thurman was hilarious and gorgeous and who knew she could dance like that, let along sing? She was a masterpiece. Will Ferrell, in my eyes, was sublime as the crazy neo-Nazi author, and when one of his pigeons gave the "heil" salute, I went over the edge.Some of the music I could have done without, but never mind. Even if you are a "Producers" purist like I am, do not miss this DVD. I have seen it 5 times and laughed like a lunatic every single time.
